awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: The benefits of yeasts to bees and bees to yeasts
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. When two species engage in an interaction that benefits both partners, it is called a mutualism. Mutualisms are widespread in the natural world, and are vital in how ecosystems function. A well-studied example of mutualisms is pollination. Insect pollinators, such as bees, have recently been discovered to have additional mutualistic interactions with microbes that live in flower nectar. This project will investigate the costs, benefits and mechanisms of mutualistic interactions for bee pollinators and nectar yeast species that are native to the southeastern United States. The Fellow will investigate these questions across several biological scales: from the genetic and cellular level up to organism responses and ecological interactions. This research will broaden the scientific understanding of pollination ecology, and help to preserve interactions among flowering plants, insects and microbes that are vital to both natural and agricultural systems. The Fellow will recruit and train undergraduate students from groups that are underrepresented in science; the results of this research will also be shared with the public at local science outreach events.
  
The Fellow will use a series of experiments to assess the costs and benefits of yeast-insect interactions, scaling from genomes to organismal response. The first experiment will investigate the genetic pathways that lead to volatile production in yeast, and determine which volatile compounds/mixtures serve as attractors to bee pollinators. Using these volatiles, the Fellow will assess whether the presence of attractive volatiles increases bee pollinator fitness indirectly via increased foraging efficiency, and/or directly by increased nutrition from ingesting yeast cells. To test whether yeast benefit from dispersal via pollinator vectors, the Fellow will test the efficacy of yeast to adhere to bee exoskeletons or survive passage through bee digestive systems, and establish growth in new nectar sources after transport. This experiment will also test the hypothesis that yeast undergo outcrossing and sexual reproduction in bee digestive tracts. During this project, the Fellow will receive training in chemical and genomic analyses, and develop technical skills in microbial biology and behavioral ecology. The Fellow will train undergraduate students in experimental design, data collection and statistical analyses during the course of the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Insects and fungi have an ancient and intertwined evolutionary history. Many fungal lineages, such as ascomycetous yeast, rely on insects for dispersal and the opportunity for increasing genetic diversity through sexual reproduction. Insects, in turn, receive nutrition, homing beacons for other resources, and microbial by-products such as bee-bread. Understanding the mechanisms, costs, and benefits of these mutualistic interactions between insects and yeast will provide key insights into the role microbes play in ecological systems. 

In this project, we investigated how bee pollinators interact with yeast that specialize in feeding on flower nectar. Yeast must be highly specialized to thrive in the high sugar environment of nectar, and rely on insects to transport them between flowers before the flower drops off of the developing fruit. Nectar yeasts produce a suite of airborne chemicals that are attractive to bee pollinators, which likely allows the yeast to hitch a ride on the feeding bee to the next flower. While recent research has shown that nectar yeast are prolific in many ecosystems, and that bees are attracted to flowers that have yeast growing in their nectar, the exact mechanisms, as well as the costs and benefits to each organism, are areas that require further study. 

We took a broad, integrative approach to this question of bee-yeast mutualisms, from a landscape survey of the presence and diversity of yeasts in local flower nectar, to the genetic mechanisms underlying pollinator attractions. By collecting nectar from populations of flowers frequented by bees in the Research Triangle of North Carolina, we were able to identify the diversity of nectar yeast species, as well as grow local strains for use in experiments. The results from our survey showed that the most prevalent yeast was the generalist Metshnikowia reukaufii, along with other Metschnikowia species, and that a surprising number of flowers had two yeast species present in their nectar; most reports find only one species per flower, as the microbes who get there first usually outcompete later arrivals. 

 

While previous laboratory research has found that bumble bees prefer nectar that contains yeast, pollinator preference for nectar yeast has not been examined in the field. Using two of our prevalent local species collected in the nectar survey (M. reukaufii and M. koreensis), we tested if bee pollinators in the wild preferred flowers filled with sterile nectar, or flowers with yeast. We found that bees that visited our experiment site (carpenter bees, bumble bees, and honey bees) preferred flowers with yeast over those without, and that they seemed to have a stronger preference for M. koreensis over sterile nectar. 

 

Saccharomyces cerevisiae, or brewer’s yeast, is one of the most well-studied organisms in the world, and is also involved in an intimate relationship with insects–fruit flies. This yeast species is known to produce chemicals that are vital for insect attraction (and therefor yeast dispersal), and that these chemicals are created by an enzyme pathway regulated by the gene ATF1. We hypothesized that this pathway may be a highly conserved method for yeasts to attract insects, and that our nectar yeast species may rely on ATF1 to attract bees the way that S. cerevisiae does to attract fruit flies. To test this hypothesis, we interrogated the genomes of M. reukaufii and M. koreensis, and found that they both contained several homologous copies of the ATF1 gene. We then cloned these genes into strains of S. cerevisiae that has been genetically altered so that it cannot express its own ATF1 gene. With this library of cloned strains, we will be able to explore what role each ATF1 homolog of nectar yeast plays in creating chemicals to attract pollinators.  

 

We also collected and analyzed the chemicals produced by M. reukaufii and M. koreensis to determine if they can create the chemicals known to be regulated by ATF1. We found that many of the chemicals controlled by ATF1 in S. cerevisiae were indeed present in our nectar yeast species. In future experiments, we can compare these chemical profiles to those produced by our ATF1 homolog clones, and determine which chemicals are controlled by which homologs. Previous research has shown that nectar yeast produce several chemicals that are detectable and attractive to bees, and we found the majority of these chemicals in our two nectar yeast species as well. Metschnikowia reukaufii and M. koreensis did not differ in the type or amount of chemicals that they produced, indicating that the stronger preference for M. koreensis might be driven by senses other than smell, such as taste.  

 

Our project has laid the foundation for future, integrative studies that can follow the pathway of yeast-insect interactions from the genetic pathways for bee attraction to the resulting distribution across the landscape.
